remarks.format:
## Remarks The <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.GridView> control raises the <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.GridView.Sorting> event when a Sort button (a button with its `CommandName` property set to "Sort") is clicked, but before the <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.GridView> control handles the sort operation. This allows you to provide an event-handling method that performs a custom routine, such as canceling the sorting operation, whenever this event occurs.
> [!NOTE] > Although any button within a <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.GridView> control with its `CommandName` property set to "Sort" will raise the <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.GridView.Sorting> event, Sort buttons typically appear in the header row of a <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.GridView> control.
A <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.GridViewSortEventArgs> object is passed to the event-handling method, which allows you to specify or determine the sort expression and sort direction in which to sort the <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.GridView> control. To determine the sort expression, use the <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.GridViewSortEventArgs.SortExpression%2A> property. To determine the sort direction, use the <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.GridViewSortEventArgs.SortDirection%2A> property. You can also cancel a sorting operation by setting the <xref:System.ComponentModel.CancelEventArgs.Cancel%2A> property to `true`.
For more information about how to handle events, see [Handling and Raising Events](~/docs/standard/events/index.md).
For a list of initial property values for an instance of <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.GridViewSortEventArgs>, see the <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.GridViewSelectEventArgs.%23ctor%2A> constructor.
## Examples The following example demonstrates how to use the <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.GridViewSortEventArgs> object passed to the event-handling method to cancel the sorting operation when the user attempts to sort the address column in a <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.GridView> control.

## Remarks When the <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.GridView.Sorting> event is raised, you can use the <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.GridViewSortEventArgs.SortDirection%2A> property to determine the order in which the <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.GridView> control will sort its items (based on the sort expression) when the sort operation is performed. Because the <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.GridView.Sorting> event occurs before the sort operation, you can also use the <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.GridViewSortEventArgs.SortDirection%2A> property to programmatically set the sort direction.
## Examples The following example demonstrates how to use the <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.GridViewSortEventArgs.SortDirection%2A> property to determine the direction in which to sort a <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.GridView> control. If the user attempts to sort in descending order, the sort operation is canceled.

remarks.format:
## Remarks When the <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.GridView.Sorting> event is raised, you can use the <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.GridViewSortEventArgs.SortExpression%2A> property to determine the sort expression that will be used to sort the <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.GridView> control when sort operation is performed. By default, the <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.GridView> control sorts a single column at a time. The sort expression simply contains the name of the field to sort. You can also sort multiple columns at a time by programmatically setting this property to a comma-separated list of field names.
## Examples The following example demonstrates how to use the <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.GridViewSortEventArgs.SortExpression%2A> property to determine which column in a <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.GridView> control is being sorted. If the user attempts to sort the address column, the sort operation is canceled.
